intro: Passovia coarctata, commonly known as the narrow-leafed pasqueflower, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the family Papaveraceae, which includes poppies and other flowering plants with showy, often brightly colored flowers. The plant is characterized by its upright stem, narrow leaves, and a single, cup-shaped flower that typically blooms in early spring. It thrives in rocky, well-drained soils and is adapted to cold climates. Passovia coarctata is known for its medicinal properties and has been used in traditional medicine for various ailments.
